newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: S&P to review Australian debt over next few months.
newsitem.headline: S&P to review Australian debt over next few months.

text.p: Standard and Poor's Corp said on Thursday that it would review Australia's credit rating in the near future.
An S&P spokeswoman told Reuters that the New York-based rating agency's sovereign debt analyst, David Beers, would come to Australia in the next few weeks to begin the review.
"We will be conducting a sovereign review over the next few months," she said.
S&P has an AA rating on Australia's foreign currency debt, with a positive outlook attached following the 1996/97 (July-June) national budget announced in August 1996.
The agency affirmed the "AA" long term and "A1-plus" short term ratings in response to the 1997/98 budget handed down on May 13 this year.
It said at the time that the budget itself would not trigger an upgrade, citing some concern about a possible mid-year deterioration in the budget position as happened in 1996/97.
The rival agency, Moody's Investors Service, said on Wednesday that Australia's AA2 rating outlook had improved, citing tight fiscal and prudent monetary policies.
A Moody's analyst told Reuters in New York earlier on Thursday that any change in the rating, however, may be up to 18 months away.
